Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Automatic Behavior Monitoring for In-depth Analysis of Construction Fatalities and Injuries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to explore computer vision-based monitoring methods, enabling the automatic and constant observation of construction workers for in-depth safety analysis. Taking into account the fact that the number of fatalities in construction remains the highest among all industries, and that approximately 80 to 90 percent of accidents are strongly associated with workers' unsafe behavior and acts, the automatic capture and systematic understanding of unsafe behavior has great potential to contribute to the reduction and prevention of injuries and fatalities in construction. Specifically, using video and image sequences, the proposed system estimates the 2D location of a human skeleton, computes the 3D location of body joints, and identifies the worker?s unsafe motions using machine learning techniques. To investigate the feasibility and potential of the proposed methods for behavior monitoring, several representative motions in traumatic (e.g., falls) and ergonomic (e.g., overexertion and repetitive motions) injuries are tested as a case study.

If successful, the findings of this research could lead to the prevention of injuries and fatalities in the construction industry by providing an in-depth understanding of human behavior and actions in terms of safety. Further, the motion analysis techniques developed in this project can be applied to diverse industries (e.g., manufacturing and shipbuilding) where labor is an important resource, providing a means to automatically collect data on human behavior and thus enabling its effective understanding. In addition, the education plan (e.g., the course that deals with understanding human behavior in safety, and the workshop planned for industry professionals and students) will provide effective education of future managers and engineers, both of whom will improve safety in the US workplace. Further, female and underrepresented students will be recruited and integrated into the planned research and education activities (e.g., safety seminars and workshops and interdisciplinary research participation opportunities).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The construction industry continues to have both a high number and rate of accidents and injuries compared to other industries, showing the highest number of fatalities among all industries and a 50% higher rate of non-fatal injuries than the all-industry average (BLS 2014; BLS 2015). Considering that the unsafe acts and behavior of workers cause 80% to 90% of accidents in construction (Heinrich et al. 1980; Salminen and Tallberg 1996; Helen and Owlinson 2005), continuous monitoring of workers is of importance to detect unsafe acts and behavior, and then to provide feedback to workers in a timely manner in order to prevent incidents. However, as the current practice for worker monitoring relies on human observations that are time-consuming and error-prone, a reliable and objective technique that requires less time and effort is needed. To address this issue, this research proposes a framework that automatically monitors and analyzes the unsafe behavior of workers and provides prompt feedback to workers on their behavior, aiming to prevent construction fatalities and injuries.

To fulfill the research objective, we applied computer vision techniques to automatically capture workers’ unsafe behavior by recording videos at sites. Video recordings of workers from multiple cameras or 3D depth sensors at the potential hazard areas (e.g., ladder climbing) were processed to extract 3D skeleton-based motion data. Based on the extracted motion data, we performed two behavior analyses: 1) motion analysis to automatically identify pre-defined unsafe actions through dimension reduction and motion classification algorithms; and 2) biomechanical analysis to evaluate excessive musculoskeletal stresses that may lead to ergonomic injuries. Our study for testing the vision-based motion capture showed the motion data extracted was accurate enough not to sacrifice the performance of behavior analyses (e.g., unsafe action detection). These behavior analyses were also tested in several occasions, showing valid results for detecting unsafe actions. The motion data and analysis results were visualized simultaneously in a virtual environment to provide workers with both feedback on their safety performance and support diverse decision-making processes. In addition to behavior analyses, computer vision techniques were applied to detect locations of workers on video images, which provides meaningful information to analyze the context of unsafe behavior.

This research enables the automatic capture and systematic understanding of the unsafe behavior of workers, contributing to the reduction and prevention of injuries and fatalities in construction. The proposed motion analysis provides an automated means to count the frequency of workers’ unsafe actions on a jobsite, and eventually, to modify workers’ behavior in a safe manner by offering feedback. Given motion data from vision-based approaches, the proposed biomechanical analysis can identify potentially hazardous construction tasks, contributing to minimizing the risks of ergonomic injuries by not only providing behavioral feedback to workers, but also redesigning work processes and environments that may cause excessive musculoskeletal stresses.

Additionally, this research reveals the feasibility of ordinary video cameras as a cost-effective and easy-to-obtain source of field data acquisition, thus providing a way to understand how planning and control decisions in daily construction can affect the safety aspects of a process. The ultimate goal of this project is to promote the safety, health, and welfare of members of our society by providing a means to observe and understand human behavior in the workplace. The proposed framework in particular may facilitate the prevention of injuries and the saving of human lives in the diverse industries where labor is an important resource.
